journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Robust adaptive integral-sliding-mode fault-tolerant control for airbreathing hypersonic vehicles

contrib-group.aff: School of Automation, Southeast University, China

author-notes.corresp: Shihua Li, Key Laboratory of Measurement and Control of CSE, School of Automation, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China. Email: lsh@seu.edu.cn

abstract.p: In this article, the problem of robust fault-tolerant tracking control is investigated for the longitudinal model of airbreathing hypersonic vehicle in the presence of actuator faults and external disturbances. First, a fault-tolerant control strategy based on finite time integral sliding mode is presented for the longitudinal model of airbreathing hypersonic vehicle, which guarantees that velocity and altitude track their reference signals in finite time. However, this method needs to know the minimum value of actuator efficiency factor and the upper bound of external disturbances. Then, an improved adaptive fault-tolerant control scheme is developed, where two adaptive laws are used to estimate the upper bound of external disturbances and the minimum value of actuator efficiency factor. Finally, simulation results show that the proposed control strategy is effective in rejecting external disturbances and handling actuator faults.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over the past decades, airbreathing hypersonic vehicle (AHV) has attracted more and more attention. On one hand, AHV is considered as a promising technology for access to space. On the other hand, it is a great challenge to design a good control system for AHV systems due to the complexity and high uncertainty of the vehicle dynamics, for instance, strong couplings between engine and flight dynamics,1,2 variation of atmospheric conditions as well as physical and aerodynamic parameters.2,3

In the face of the complex system, numerous control schemes have been reported based on the model obtained by approximate linearization in given flight conditions in the past decades. A linear stochastic robust control law is presented in Marrison and Stengel.4 Using linear matrix inequality (LMI) technique, a guaranteed cost law is developed in Li et al.5 Although the tracking performances of the system from different aspects are improved under the aforesaid control schemes, these controllers may provide unsatisfactory performances when the flight conditions are far from the nominal operating point. Then, to obtain a better control performance, many nonlinear control strategies, including adaptive control,6–8 robust control,9,10H∞ control,11 back-stepping control,12,13 sliding-mode control,3,14 disturbance observer-based control,15 neural-network control,12,16,17 and fuzzy-logic control,18,19 have been presented for the longitudinal model of AHV.

However, when the AHV executes tasks, it must face atrocious environmental conditions during a wide range of flight envelopes. This may lead to actuator faults, which are usually unknown. These aspects not only degrade the control performance of AHV but also may lead to system instability and even more catastrophic accidents. To improve AHV dynamics’ safety and reliability, a fault-tolerant control scheme would be an effective method. The fault-tolerant control method can be mainly classified into two cases: passive and active.20 The main idea of the passive fault-tolerant control approach is that the same controller is designed for both the normal case and the faults case.21–24 Hence, these passive fault-tolerant controllers are easily implemented. The aim of an active fault-tolerant control scheme is to synthesize a new controller online to compensate for the effect of faults.25–28

At present, some fault-tolerant control schemes are reported for AHVs. 21,25,29,30 However, they mainly concentrate on the attitude dynamics system, except Li et al.29 Because of the differences between attitude control system and the longitudinal model of AHV, the control methods in Jiang et al.,21 Gao et al.,25 and Xu et al.30 on attitude control system are not easily applied to the longitudinal model of AHV. In addition, in Li et al.,29 according to the model obtained by approximate linearization in given flight conditions, a fault-tolerant control strategy is developed. This scheme may not obtain good control performances when flight dynamics undergo great parameter perturbations because of tough flight task and adverse flight environment.

Since this article concerns with sliding-mode control, some remarkable results on this field should not be ignored. Sliding-mode control is regarded as an effective method to cope with external disturbances, nonlinear perturbations, and parametric uncertainties for nonlinear systems, which has good robust and disturbance rejection performances. The conventional sliding-mode control approach usually chooses linear sliding-mode manifolds to design controllers for nonlinear systems.31,32 However, the linear sliding-mode controllers only make system states converge to an equilibrium point asymptotically, which means convergence in infinite time.

To speed up the convergence of sliding-mode control systems, an improved method is to utilize nonlinear sliding-mode manifolds, for example, terminal sliding modes (TSM). Compared with the linear sliding-mode controllers, the TSM controllers ensure that the system states converge to an equilibrium point in finite time. Besides, TSM control systems also possess a better disturbance rejection performance. In view of these merits, TSM has received more and more attention and has been widely applied in many control fields, such as bioreactor systems,33 spacecraft control systems,34 robotic control systems35 and so on. However, it has been reported that the TSM controllers may lead to singularity of the closed-loop system.35,36 To avoid such a problem, a switching control scheme is used in Wu et al.36 The trajectory under this control law can be driven to a specified open region in which the singular phenomenon is avoided. However, the singularity problem is not solved essentially. For this purpose, a nonsingularity TSM is developed in Feng et al.,35 but this scheme is only suitable for second-order systems. For a class of high-order nonlinear systems, a kind of finite-time integral sliding mode is proposed in Zong et al.37

In this article, the problem of tracking control for the longitudinal model of AHV subject to external disturbances and actuator faults is investigated based on finite-time integral-sliding-mode control method.37 As compared with the existing results, the main contributions of this article are as follows. First, two fault-tolerant control schemes are designed for the longitudinal model of AHV in the presence of external disturbances and actuator faults, where the first one can guarantee that velocity and altitude track their reference signals in finite time. Second, two adaptive laws are developed to estimate the upper bound of external disturbances and the minimum value of actuator efficiency factor in the second control scheme. No information on the disturbances and actuator faults is required by the second control scheme.

The rest of this article is organized as follows. In the next section, model description is formulated. The input–output linearization model of the longitudinal model of AHV is demonstrated in section “Input-output linearization model.” The main results are given in section “Fault-tolerant tracking controller design,” where two fault-tolerant control methods are developed for the longitudinal model of AHV in the presence of external disturbances and actuator faults. In section “Simulation results,” simulation results are discussed, while section “Conclusions and future work” concludes this article.

sec.title: Mathematical model of the longitudinal model of AHV
sec.p: The longitudinal model of AHV is presented as3
where

The variable q¯ denotes the dynamic pressure and satisfies q¯=12ρV2, while V, γ, h, α, and q represent velocity, flight path angle, altitude, angle of attack, and pitch rate of the AHV, respectively. T, D, L, Myy, δE, and β represent thrust, drag, lift, pitching moment, elevator deflection angle, and throttle setting, respectively. d1(t) denotes the external disturbances.
The engine dynamics are modeled by a second-order system3

where βc is a demand of the control input. m, ρ, Iyy, S, μ, and Re represent mass of the hypersonic vehicle, density of air, moment of inertia, reference area, gravitational constant, and radius of the earth, respectively. c¯ and ce are constants. Moreover, the outputs are the velocity V and the altitude h.

list-item.p: Assumption 1. The external disturbances, d1(t), are supposed to be bounded and satisfy ‖d1(t)‖≤ϕ, where ϕ is an upper bound of the external disturbances.

and Lgk(Lfj−1(hi)) satisfies the following conditions

Then, (r1,…,rm) is called the relative degree of the nonlinear system (7). If r=r1+⋯+rm=n, the nonlinear system (7) can be completely transformed to a linear system. If r<n, the nonlinear system (7) can only be partially linearized, where the stability of the system (7) relies on the stability of zero dynamics.

Using the aforesaid method to the longitudinal model of AHV, we can compute the derivative of the system outputs V and h until the control inputs appear in the final functions. Based on this aim, the output dynamics V and h can be obtained by differentiating three times and four times, respectively. Therefore, r=4+3=7=n, and the longitudinal model can be completely linearized as follows

Remark 1. The matrix B0 turns to be singular in the case of a vertical flight path, that is, γ=±π/2.3,9 Since γ is quite small during the cruise phrase,8,12 this assumption is reasonable.

sec.title: Fault-tolerant tracking controller design
sec.p: In this section, two different control schemes are presented to solve the tracking control problem for the longitudinal model of AHV in the presence of external disturbances and actuator faults. First, a fault-tolerant control scheme based on finite-time integral-sliding-mode control is designed, which guarantees velocity and altitude track of the reference signals in finite time. However, this method requires some information regarding external disturbances and actuator faults. In order to efficiently implement the control scheme, an improved fault-tolerant control method is developed, where two adaptive laws are employed to estimate the upper bound of external disturbances and the minimum value of the actuator efficiency factor. Before presenting the control schemes, the vehicle model with actuator faults is given and some lemmas are recalled, which will be used in the subsequent control development and analysis.
The vehicle model with actuator faults is presented by

where Λi is a time-varying parameter, i=1,2, and is subject to 0≤Λi≤1. Λi=1 represents that the actuator works properly. Λi=0 denotes that the actuator failed completely. 0<Λi<1 means that the actuator failed partially, but it still has effect all the time. In this section, an assumption 0<Λi≤1 is given. Let Λmin=min{Λ1,Λ2}, which is a positive number. Then, define Θ=1Λmin, which belongs to [1,+∞).

sec.title: An improved fault-tolerant tracking controller design
sec.p: Using control law (27), V and h track reference signals Vd and hd in finite time in the presence of external disturbances and actuator faults, respectively, but the control scheme (27) has two drawbacks.

list-item.p: In AHV systems, it is difficult to obtain the precise information of the upper bound of external disturbances. Similar to actuator faults, the minimum value of actuator efficiency factor cannot be obtained easily. This means that the values ϕ and Λmin may not be available in the practical system.

To guarantee that the system has a good disturbance rejection performance, the upper bound of external disturbances needs to be chosen large enough when the upper bound of external disturbances is not exactly known. This inaccuracy worsens the chattering which is caused by sliding-mode control.

sec.p: Hence, in order to ensure that the control scheme performs more efficiently, an improved fault-tolerant control scheme is proposed, which has the following advantages. First, the control method does not use any information about the faults. Then, an estimated value of the upper bound of external disturbances is obtained by an adaptive control scheme.

list-item.p: Theorem 2. Consider system (20) with Assumption 2, the following control scheme is implemented

sec.p: where sliding-mode manifolds s1 and s2 are same as equations (24) and (25), γi>0, Γi>0, εi>0, i=1,2, 0<τ<1, sigτ(·)=sign(·)|·|τ, P=diag{P1,P2}, P1 and P2 are positive numbers, and Proj is a projection operator,41 which is adopted in the parameter update law, and the modified system is presented by
Then the tracking errors ev and eh, can be driven into a neighborhood of the sliding-mode manifolds s1 and s2 in finite time, respectively.

where 0<θ1<1. If s∉Ω, we have
Next, we will prove that s is driven into Ω in finite time. Obviously, there are two cases for all initial states.

One case is that they are outside of Ω. Since V·2<0, there exists a t1 such that s(t1)∈bdΩ, where bdΩ is the boundary of Ω. Another case is that they are within Ω. If s remains in Ω and never goes above it, we do not need to prove it. We only consider the case that s will escape from Ω. For this case, there is also a t1>0 such that s∈bdΩ. Now let us certify that s∈Ω for every t∈[t1,∞). The proof is inspired by Bhat and Bernstein.38
Let χ=infs∈bdΩ‖s||τ+1, then χ=η0/(θ1γ¯). Furthermore, we have

Since V2 is continuous, it can be derived that there is an n1>0, such that s∈Ω for all t∈[t1,t1+n1). Assume that there exists a t0∈[t1,∞) such that s∉Ω. Then, there exists a t3∈(t1,t0), such that s(t3)∈bdΩ.
Noting that V·2≤−(1−θ1)γχ<0, and combining with the continuity of V2, there exists an arbitrarily small n2>0 such that V2 is monotonously decreasing on [t3−n2,t3). Now we obtain

which is a contradiction. Hence, we reach a conclusion s∈Ω, ∀t≥t1. Thus, it is derived that the control scheme (38) makes the tracking errors ev and eh converge to a neighborhood of the sliding-mode manifolds s1 and s2 in finite time, respectively.

list-item.p: Remark 2. The control scheme (38) does not use the parameter Λmin, and thus, the control method can be effectively applied to deal with fault-tolerant control problems for the longitudinal model of AHV with actuator faults. Moreover, the upper bound of external disturbances is not employed to design the control scheme as well. Instead, the upper bound of external disturbances is estimated by adaptive control technique. Hence, all the problems existing in the controller (27) are solved by the controller (38).

Remark 3. From equation (50), it is concluded that the parameter γi needs to be selected large enough such that there is a smaller boundary layer about the sliding-mode manifolds. This is clear from equation (49), that the tracking errors eh and ev cannot converge to zero, but a larger γi is employed to guarantee that the tracking errors eh and ev are small enough.

Remark 4. Equation (50) states that the parameter η0 also determines the region of the boundary layer, which means that the parameter εi is related to the region of the boundary layer, that is, the smaller region of the boundary layer, the smaller the parameter εi required. However, the parameter εi cannot be chosen too small, because it also impacts the convergence speed of the estimated parameters ϕ^ and Θ^. Therefore, a compromise should be reached between the region of the boundary layer and the convergence rate of the estimated parameters ϕ^ and Θ^.

Remark 5. Note that control strategies (27) and (38) include the term: B0TPs/‖sTPB0‖. This may cause undesirable chattering of the closed-loop system. According to Choi,42 a function B0TPs/(‖sTPB0‖+ϖ), where ϖ is a positive constant, is employed to eliminate the chattering. Then, the corresponding controllers can be rewritten as

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p: In this section, simulation results are provided to confirm the effectiveness of the proposed adaptive fault-tolerant control scheme (53). As a representative case study, the vehicle is initially trimmed at V=15,060ft/s and h=110,000ft. The model parameters are given as9

To demonstrate the robustness of the proposed control scheme, parameter uncertainties are selected as Δm=−0.03,ΔI=−0.03, while ΔS=0.03, Δc¯=0.03,Δρ=0.03, and Δce=0.03. The external disturbances are presented as d1(t)=0.01sin(t), which work on system at t=30s.
The reference signals Vd and hd are given as 15,160ft/s and 112,000ft, respectively. The controller parameters are chosen as
In order to verify the effectiveness of the proposed fault-tolerant control scheme, two types of fault scenarios are considered, and the simulation results are presented as follows.

sec.title: Case I: tracking control under constant faults scenario
sec.p: The faults are assumed as

Performance index of the closed-loop system are presented in Table 1. Figure 1(a) and (b) depict the tracking curves of altitude and velocity, respectively. Curves of the sliding-mode manifolds shown in Figure 1(f) demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Curves of elevator deflection angle δE, throttle setting of engine β, and control input command βc are given in Figure 1(c) to (e), respectively.

caption.p: Performance index of the closed-loop system in the first case

Response curves of hypersonic vehicle variables under controller from equation (53) in the first case: (a) altitude h, (b) velocity V, (c) elevator deflection angle δE, (d) throttle setting of engine β, (e) the demand of the control input βc, and (f) sliding-mode manifolds.

sec.p: The effectiveness of the proposed method can be seen in Figure 1. The simulation results demonstrate that although there are actuator faults and external disturbances in the system, the tracking performance can be guaranteed and satisfactory system responses can be obtained.

sec.title: Case II: tracking control under time-varying faults scenario
sec.p: The faults are assumed as

Performance index of the closed-loop system are given in Table 2. The results of the simulations are shown in Figure 2. The tracking curves for altitude and velocity are displayed in Figure 2(a) and (b), respectively, which demonstrates that the proposed method can guarantee that the closed-loop system has good robustness against external disturbances and actuator faults. The output velocity and altitude effectively track the reference signals under the proposed control scheme. Figure 2(f) shows the curves of the sliding-mode manifolds. Figure 2(c)–(e) describe curves of elevator deflection angle δE, throttle setting of engine β, and control input command βc, respectively.

caption.p: Performance index of the closed-loop system in the second case

Response curves of hypersonic vehicle variables under controller in equation (53) in the second case: (a) altitude h, (b) velocity V (c) elevator deflection angle δE, (d) throttle setting of engine β (e) the demand of the control input βc, and (f) sliding-mode manifolds.

sec.title: Conclusions and future work
sec.p: Two fault-tolerant control schemes based on finite-time integral-sliding-mode control technique have been proposed for the longitudinal model of the AHV in the presence of actuator faults and external disturbances. Moreover, the latter control method does not require any information about the faults or any methods of fault detection and isolation, where two adaptive laws have been employed to estimate the minimum value of actuator effectiveness factor and the upper bound of external disturbances, respectively. In addition, the stability analysis of the closed-loop system has been done using the Lyapunov direct approach. Finally, simulation results have been presented to evaluate the closed-loop system performance with the proposed control scheme and show its robustness to external disturbances and actuator faults.

Switched control method can enhance the system control performance43 and reliability.44 In view of these advantages, switched control method has been applied to the flight control system and some remarkable results have been presented in Xu et al.45 and Hou et al.46 In recent times, switched system has received more attention, and many meaningful results have been reported.47–50 Based on these ideas, switched control method can be employed to deal with the problem of fault-tolerant control or other control problems for AHV in future.
